Description.val:
This line item funds Common Electronic Countermeasures (ECM) equipment for strike and assault aircraft.  The overall goal of the modification budget is to provide a reprogrammable radar and missile warning system, provide attacking missile declaration, sector direction finding, laser detection, and self-protection capability devices to applicable user aircraft. It will also provide for the integration of hardware/software solutions that link on-board integrated Aircraft Survivability Equipment (iASE) that are compatible with mission planning information.

Operational Safety Improvements Program (OSIP) 014-90 AN/APR-39(V)2 Radar Warning Receiver (RWR): The AN/APR-39A/B/C/D (V) 2 Radar Signal Detecting Set is designed for United States Marine Corps (USMC), United States Navy (USN), United States Air Force (USAF), and United States Army (US Army) Assault Support aircraft to provide onboard situational awareness and warning of radar threats. NRE, integration, validation/ verification and procurement of the upgraded APR-39 system (APR-39D (V)2) will continue through FY 2031. 

OSIP 006-00 ALE-39 to ALE-47 Retrofit: This OSIP provides funding for retrofit installation of AN/ALE-47 on F/A-18/C/D aircraft lots 12-17 and to procure new AN/ALE-47 Test Sets (ALM-290) to replace original version ALM-286s. The replacement of the AN/ALE-39 Dispenser system with the AN/ALE-47 will correct serious safety problems and greatly improve aircraft survivability.

OSIP 005-08 Direct Infrared Countermeasure (DIRCM) / Department of Navy Large Aircraft Infrared Countermeasure (DoN LAIRCM) AN/AAQ-24: This OSIP provides current available technology improvements for survivability to United States Marine Corps aircraft.  This budget supports procurement, Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs), integration, validation, Follow-on Test and Evaluation (FOT&E) and fielding of DoN LAIRCM systems on CH-53E/K, KC-130J, P-8A and MV-22 platforms.

OSIP 004-12 Common On-Board Jammer: Integrated Defensive Electronic Counter Measure (IDECM) Block 4 is an ECP to the ALQ-214 intended to render it suitable for operation on the F/A-18C/D aircraft, while retaining all IDECM suite functionality when installed on F/A-18E/F aircraft. The Electronic Frequency Converter (EFC) enables dataflow via the fiber optic cable to the Fiber Optic Towed Decoy (FOTD) and is part of the IB-4 configuration when installed on the F/A-18E/F aircraft. This OSIP is for the onboard portion of the IB-4 configuration. 

OSIP 017-12 Correction of Discrepancies: This OSIP will provide the required correction to multiple sub-components that are obsolete.

OSIP 004-15 Assault Correction of Discrepancies: Assault of Corrections of Discrepancies OSIP will affect changes to assault Electronic Countermeasure (ECM) equipment in the aircraft that have been delivered for fleet operations. These ECM systems require various upgrade initiatives to keep these aircraft mission capable with a robust defensive system that ensure aircraft survivability.

OSIP 018-17 Assault Direct Infrared Countermeasures (ADIRCM): This OSIP provides funding for the installation of Assault Direct Infrared Countermeasures on the United States Navy/United States Marine Corps chosen material solution for AH-1Z, UH-1Y, and MH-60S aircraft initiated as a response to Joint Urgent Operational Needs Statement (SO-0010).

Justification.val:
FY20 Baseline funding is required for Common Electronic Countermeasures (ECM) equipment for strike and assault aircraft.

OCO: 
FY20 OCO funding provided to procure 1 DIRCM "B" Kit for MV-22 and other support.

Model.val: UH-1Y, AH-1Z, MV-22,  KC-130T, CH-53E/K, KC-130J, MH-53, HH-60H, MH-60S

Name.@footnote: FY20 cost increased to support the D(V)2 System ECP integration for the CH-53E.
D(V) Systems software increased due to resolving software deficiencies discovered during ground and flight test.  FY20 cost increased to support the D(V)2 System Software integration for the CH-53E.

Price difference between V-22 and H-1 is because the V-22 configuration requires two additional receivers.  FY20 quantities and cost increased to support the V-22 retrofit; FY21-24 the system cost increases per the cost model projections.
FY20 qty and cost increased to support the H-1 retrofit.

Name.val: 1.1.3) Install Equip AN/APR-39 D(V)2 - CH-53E - Organic
1.1.4) Install Equipment Conversion B Kits - Organic

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION / JUSTIFICATION: The AN/APR-39 family of systems Radar Signal Detecting Set is designed for United States Marine Corps (USMC), United States Navy (USN), United States Air Force (USAF) and United States Army (US Army) Assault Support aircraft to provide onboard situational awareness and warning of radar threats by Statement of Operational Requirements Document (ORD) number 545-88-00 dated 14 February 2000. The AN/APR-39 family of systems provides control and display of the AN/AAQ-24, AN/AAQ-45, AN/AAR-47, AN/AAR-59 and AN/AAR-61 Missile Warning Systems (MWS) and Chaff dispense commands to the AN/ALE-47 Counter Measure Dispensing System (CMDS).  The AN/APR-39 consists of five antennas, one Cockpit Control unit, one Processor, a display, and two, three, or four receivers (dependent on a/c configuration).  This OSIP supports: Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs); software upgrades; Modernized Radar Warning Receiver (MRWR) Capabilities Development Document (CDD) and Radar Frequency Countermeasures (RFCM) upgrades and interface/integrations to include Integrated Aircraft Survivability Equipment (iASE).  This program develops integrated hardware/software solutions that link Onboard iASE that are compatible with mission planning information.  This program has the capability to store sensor data for post mission threat analysis.  Updates required through the Future Year Defense Program (FYDP) for various platforms. The AN/APR-39D(V)2 corrects deficiencies documented in the AN/APR-39 A/B/C variants by providing correct direction of arrival (DOA) information, resolving time delayed detection and identification of threat emitters improving situational awareness to combat aircrews.  The AN/APR-39 family of systems are installed on the following USMC and USN assault support aircraft: V-22, H-1, H-60, H-53 and C-130.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: The APR-39 is in the production and sustainment phase (MSIII3Q/96). The Department of Navy is the lead service of this joint service program.  Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE), integration, validation/verification and procurement of the upgraded APR-39 system (APR-39D(V)2) will continue through FY 2031.

Model.val: CH-53E, EA-6B,UH-1N, MH-53E, F/A-18C/D, AV-8B, MV-22, KC-130F/R/T, H-60, P-3

Name.val: 3.1) Archived Support Costs No Longer Funded In FYDP

Name.@footnote: F/A-18 ALM-290 Test Sets: FY 2019 cost increase for the ALM-290 test sets is due to implementation of AFC-566 which increases ALE-47 O-Level maintenance test equipment allowances per squadron, requiring additional quantity procurement. In addition, ALM-290 unit cost increase of the ALM-290s is due to redesign for miscellaneous components obsolescence.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Depot Level Installation:: Installation Name: F/A-18C Installation Costs

Name.@footnote: F/A-18 A-Kit:   During FY 2017 thru FY 2020 A-kits are being procured for F/A-18C 2-dispenser, F/A-18D 2-dispenser, and F/A-18D 4-dispenser configurations.  The A-kit components and unit costs vary, depending on which type, model, series (TMS) being modified and quantity of dispensers (2 or 4 each) per TMS.  The FY 2019 cost increase was driven by additional F/A-18Ds becoming available for Air Frame Change (AFC)-566, which requires (4) dispensers and requires increased hours to complete modification.  Commander, Naval Air Forces (CNAF) is continuing extension of flight hours and service life on the F/A-18s, possibly to FY 2031, to fill strike fighter shortfall, requiring additional aircraft modifications.    FY19 Congressional action reduced FY19 funded installations from (25) to (15) aircraft. FY20 added (5) retrofit installations creating a new To-Complete quantity of (29) for the planned aircraft modifications to accommodate F/A-18 aircraft with extended service life. To Complete Cost increase for installations is due to remaining installations being F-18D four (4) dispenser configuration which increases both hardware and labor installation above prior two (2) dispenser aircraft configurations.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Depot Level Installation:: Installation Name: F/A-18C Installation Costs

Name.@footnote: F/A-18 B Kits: FY 2019 B-Kit cost increase is due to procurement of new B-kit components (prior year B-kit components were reused or reconditioned from retiring aircraft with ALE-47 installed). B-kit unit cost and the component quantities vary depending on aircraft configuration: "D" model aircraft have (4) dispensers vice (2) for "C" model aircraft. The Technical Directive for AFC-566 was approved to allow for stand-alone modifications, which provides increased schedule flexibility ALE-47 Retrofit aircraft induction without schedule delays of concurrent aircraft modifications. FY20 added (5), leaving a Cost-To-Complete quantity of (29) for the planned aircraft modifications to accommodate F/A-18 aircraft with extended service life. To Complete Cost increase for installations is due to remaining installations being F-18D four (4) dispenser configuration which increases both hardware and labor installation above prior two (2) dispenser aircraft configurations.

Installation Equipment FY18 Budget of $3.65M was added for the procurement of Circuit Cards Assemblies to retrofit ALE-47 programmers on aircraft scheduled for incorporation but unable to get upgraded capability during production due to contract delays.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  The replacement of the AN/ALE-39 Dispenser System with the AN/ALE-47 will correct serious safety problems and greatly improve aircraft survivability. As a joint program, Under Secretary of Defense (Acquisition Technology & Logistics) memo of November 1986 directed the United States Navy (USN) and United States Army (US Army) to participate in the United States Air Force (USAF) Engineering Manufacturing Development (EMD) phase. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  The AN/ALE-47 system is in production and being installed in multiple USN, USMC and USAF aircraft. This OSIP provides funding for retrofit installation of AN/ALE-47 on F/A-18/C/D aircraft lots 12-17 and to procure new AN/ALE-47 Test Sets (ALM-290) to replace original version ALM-286s.

FY18 Budget increased by $10.65M, in which $7M was due to the ALE-47 System implementing an organic government Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) to upgrade both hardware and software of the AN/ALE-47 Countermeasures Dispensing Set (CMDS) Programmer in FY18/19.  This change will allow for one common Operational Flight Program (OFP) configuration with requirements derived from integrated Aircraft Survivability Equipment (iASE) initial capabilities document (ICD) in support of improved aircrew situational awareness and the baseline for interfacing with platform ASE sensors and Position, Navigation and Time (PNT) data. The ECP modification will take legacy systems and prime them to digitally interface with emerging aircraft networks, thus increasing platform survivability and battlespace awareness for ownship, wingman, and FOB commands.  The capability aligns with and supports Joint networked CONOPS for survivability and lethality. The remaining $3.65M was a result of procuring Power PC Circuit Card Assemblies to retrofit ALE-47 programmers on aircraft scheduled for incorporation but unable to get upgraded capability during production. 

FY 2020 is last funded year, leaving a Cost-to-Complete quantity of (29) for the planned aircraft modifications to accommodate F/A-18 aircraft with extended service life.

Operational Program Improvement associated with commonality of expendable form factors across DoD and Joint Partners is future focus for Common Carriage Program providing an increase in expendable capacity and operational readiness while reducing logistics footprint.

Name.@footnote: Software Upgrade funding increases to support multiple platform integration and S/W encryption of the system OFP and the processor upgrade software.

Name.val: 2.7) Archived Support Cost No Longer Funded in FYDP

Name.@footnote: DoN LAIRCM unit cost varies based on platform configuration (WRA qty) and combined procurements for other customers. FY21-24: MV-22 Total Quantity initially assumed 1/3 of MV-22s would receive GLTAs (completed in 2021); the remainder would be procured without GLTA.  MV-22 has determined final configuration will be full B-kits (to include GLTAs) for all installs. The increase in unit cost based on full B-kits results in deltas each year for MV-22 and KC-130J requirements for FY-21-24.
1.2.1 FY20 funding increased in FY20 to support the lead platform aircraft integration.
FY19 - FY22 Navy Test increased to support the Lead Platform Aircraft test.

Name.val: 1.2.4) Archived B Kits Non Recurring - Organic

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: The AN/AAQ-24 Department of the Navy, Large Aircraft Infrared Countermeasures (DoN LAIRCM) System (B-kit) consists of 5 components: Missile Warning Sensor (MWS, 5 or 6), processor (1), Guardian Laser Transmitter Assembly (GLTA, 2) and Controller Interface Unit (CIU) (1). The Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA) System Threat Assessment Report (STAR) and current United States Marine Corps (USMC) operations pose surface to air threats requiring DoN LAIRCM capabilities to maintain survivability against improved Man-Portable Air Defense Systems (MANPADS), Rocket Propelled Grenades (RPG), hostile gunfire, Anti-Aircraft Artillery (AAA) and laser-directed weapons.  This budget supports procurement, Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs), integration, validation, Follow-on Test and Evaluation (FOT&E) and fielding of DoN LAIRCM systems on CH-53E/K, KC-130J, P-8A, CMV-22 and MV-22 platforms in accordance with Statement of Operational Requirement Document (ORD) number 756-88-08. Based on FY 2015 Joint Urgent Operational Needs Statement (JUONS) SO-0010, United States Special Operations Command (SOCOM) and United States of Army (USA) programs have approved requirements for DoN LAIRCM integration.   This program has the capability to store sensor data for post mission threat analysis.  The DoN LAIRCM program integrates hardware/software solutions that link onboard integrated Aircraft Survivability Equipment (iASE) which are compatible with the mission planning information.  The DoN LAIRCM configurations include the 5 or 6 sensor, the GLTA or the Non-GLTA.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  DoN LAIRCM program achieved MS C/ Full Rate Production in January 2010.  The Engineering Change Proposals (ECP) provide required improvements and address identified deficiencies (e.g. Advanced Threat Warning (ATW) to improved Missile Warning Sensor (MWS) Probability of detection (Pd), False Alarm Reduction (FAR), threat information for Smart Dispensing, Hostile Fire Indication (HFI) and Laser Warning (LW)).  FY2018 OCO funding procured 12 DoN LAIRCM B-kits with ATW sensor capability for MV-22 aircraft supporting SPMAGTF operations. FY18 A/C Integration NRE cost increased due to Processor upgrade requirements.  FY18 B-kit quantity reduced by four systems and reduced S/W Upgrade funding and realigned funds to support DoN LAIRCM Processor Upgrade (DLPU) and A/C Integration NRE. FY20 funds will procure LRIP DLPU assets to integrate and validate the upgraded DoN LAIRCM system in 2021.

Name.@footnote: ALQ-214 Other Support: Funding supports annual ALQ-214 Repair and Field Support Contract as well as Program and Engineering Support.
FY 2019 funds realigned to support ALQ-214 peculiar support equipment requirements to Improve Repair Turnaround Time(RTAT)on the ALQ-214 WRA NAVAIR Test Assets.

$20M Navy UFR: F/A-18E/F Super Hornet Adaptive RADAR countermeasures (DRTG G2 SRA Retrofit)

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  Integrated Defensive Electronic Countermeasure (IDECM) Block (IB-4)  is an Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) to the ALQ-214 intended to render it suitable for operation on the F/A-18C/D aircraft equipped with ALR-67(V)2 or ALR-67(V)3 Radar Warning Receivers, while retaining all IDECM suite functionality when installed on F/A-18E/F aircraft. This ECP will result in a Common On-Board Jammer (COBJ) system that must meet the requirements of the COBJ Block 2 Operational Requirements Document (ORD) #624-78-03 and be compatible with the ALE-55 Fiber Optic Towed Decoy (FOTD). The Integrated Multi-Platform Launch Controller (IMPLC) provides power and communications interface with the ALE-50 and ALE-55 components of the IDECM EW Suite on the F/A-18 E/F aircraft. The Electronic Frequency Converter (EFC) enables dataflow via the fiber optic cable to the FOTD and is part of the IB-4 configuration when installed on the F/A-18E/F aircraft. This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) is for the onboard portion of the IB-4 configuration. This OSIP also includes procurement of hardware/software solutions that link on-board integrated Aircraft Survivability Equipment (iASE) that are compatible with mission planning information and systems intended to address current and future aircraft threats and modeling and simulation for improved countermeasure capabilities.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: The ALQ-214 received Milestone III approval in January 2004 and is still in Full-Rate Production (FRP). FRP 9 was the first ALQ-214 production lot in the IB-4 configuration and was awarded 3rd Qtr FY 2012. Annual production contract awards are expected to continue through FY 2027. A total of 324 IB-4 ALQ-214s are planned for procurement.

Name.@footnote: FY19 fund execution realigned into Other Support to address software discrepancies in Assault aircrafts.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) is for the correction of discrepancies to affect changes to assault Electronic Countermeasure (ECM) equipment in aircraft that have been delivered for fleet operations. These ECM systems require various upgrade initiatives and logistic support to keep these aircraft mission capable with a robust defensive system that ensures its survivability. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: The contract will modify shop replaceable assemblies with diminished manufacturing source issues and conduct engineering change proposals, and verify testing and evaluations of modification designs. The United States Navy Fleet Support Team will provide system engineering qualifications on aircraft, support equipment, write technical directives, upgrade technical data and perform any additional integrated logistics support requirements. United States Navy and contractor software support activities will integrate software as needed.

Name.@footnote: FY19 Other Support:  Funding supports Support Equipment modifications, program, engineering and test support.  Realignment of funds into "other support" occurred as an isolated event in FY19 due to cost savings achieved in negotiations.
FY18 quantities increased by 6 systems due to cost savings achieved during contract negotiations.  FY19 quantities were procured with FY18 funds.

Description.val:
Description:  Assault Directed Infrared Countermeasure (ADIRCM) is the budget name for DAIRCM which is a lightweight Threat Warning System (TWS) and Infrared Countermeasure (IRCM) developed by the Navy Research Lab under an FY 2004 Office of Naval Research Future Naval Capability (FN04-03), Integrated E/O IR Self-Protect Suite for Rotary Wing Aircraft.  PMA272 has funded this Future Naval Capability (FNC) since 2006 as a risk mitigation for both the Joint and Allied Threat Awareness System (JATAS) and the Common Infrared Countermeasures (CIRCM) system. The DAIRCM nomenclature is the AAQ-45 System which offers significant savings in Size, Weight and Power (SWaP) and cost avoidance. The system consists of a centralized processor and laser with high power fiber optic cables leading to 4-6 two-color IR sensors. Each sensor incorporates a pointer tracker, which allows laser energy to be focused on incoming threats. 

FY 2017 through FY 2019 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) funds for AAQ-45 provides increased survivability against Man-Portable Air Defense Systems (MANPADS), Rocket Propelled Grenades (RPG), hostile gunfire, Anti-Aircraft Artillery (AAA) and laser-directed weapons for combat, assault rotary wing and fixed wing aircraft in theater. FY 2017 OCO funds completed the original Joint Urgent Operational Need Statement (JUONS) fielding requirements. FY 2018 OCO funds are required to procure assets in support of fielding two additional Marine Expeditionary Units (MEUs). The FY 2018 OCO ensures the capability to conduct missions in areas where the JUONS threat exists until the Program of Record (PoR) assets can be fielded. FY 2019 OCO funds are required to procure assets in support of fielding MH-60S on two additional MEU's.


Developmental efforts:  JUONS phase includes the Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE) required to develop integrate and test all hardware, software and firmware to field AAQ-45. Efforts will also include the manufacturing of AAQ-45 test articles, test bench fixtures, fleet representative hardware and system training. The driving requirements can be found in the classified JUONS SO-0010 and the classified Request for Initiation of Rapid Deployment Capability (RDC) process for an Advanced Threat Warning and Inexhaustible Infrared Countermeasure for Rotary Wing Aircraft (RDC Ser N9/16S139158).   Two prime contractors, DRS and Daylight Solutions were awarded sole source contracts for the AAQ-45 Weapons Replaceable Assemblies (WRA).  During the JUONS phase, the AAQ-45 system will be installed on the following United States Navy (USN)/United States Marine Corps (USMC) aircraft identified in JUONS SO-0010:  AH-1Z, UH-1Y, and MH-60S. The AAQ-45 configuration on these aircraft will include one processor, one laser and four sensors. The USN's MH-60S is the lead platform for AAQ-45 JUONS configuration.
